comments.body: This feels a bit hacky. Maybe that's a bias coming from Haskell, but to me `withOnLedger` implies that the `onLedger` should be limited to the scope of the continuation and should not leak out. Either `machine.getOnLedger` or moving `machine.withOnLedger` to the relevant places would seem cleaner.
Yeah I agree that itâ€™s a bit weird. The reason why I went for this is that the machine is t the class level so it seems weird to limit the scope of the onledger stuff to anything less.
Iâ€™ve inlined the implementation in those two cases to make this a bit less confusing.
Thanks, yes, that's clearer.

comments.body: I don't see a consequence for this match branch.

This is legal scala syntax. It means the same as having `()` on RHS of the `=>`

But I agree, I generally prefer when code is explicit with `()`, but I missed it here.
Since that code has changed anyway, can we please add the `()` here.
